html.default:
This is a work in progress and changes may be made regularly. You can follow its development and even participate by joining us on the GitHub project repository.

If you find a bug or if you encounter a problem, please create an issue on the project site.

Can I use this project for my government or company?

Yes, this is an open source project released under the MIT licence and you are welcome to use it for your own needs. See the link above for the project repository.

Please provide notice of licence and attribution of the work where required.

What is the DORA Self-Assessment?

It is a questionnaire designed to help you assess your alignement with DevOps practices as per the DevOps Research and Assessment (DORA) set of metrics and suggest possible ways to improve your DevOps practice.

How does it work?

The questionnaire asks you questions related to your business process, tools and organizational environment. The results will demonstrate your alignement level as well as propose ways to improve certain areas of your work.

Where can I find out about my results?

When you complete the questionnaire, a detailed results page will be displayed. You can print it or save it as PDF.

Can I save my responses and complete the questionnaire later?

Yes. When you want to save your progress, click on the 'Save' button at the top of the window and save the JSON file (machine readable structure text document) to your local folders. If you want to continue where you left off, click on the 'Choose file' button and select your saved JSON file.

Do you store my answers?

No. We don't store your responses and data only remains within your browser's local storage. Feel free to use this tool as many times as you want to.

All data will be deleted if you click on the button 'Start over'
html.fr:
Il s'agit d'un travail en cours et des changements peuvent être apportés régulièrement. Vous pouvez suivre son évolution et même y participer en nous rejoignant sur le GitHub dépôt du projet.

Si vous trouvez un bug ou si vous rencontrez un problème, veuillez créer un publié sur le site du projet.<

Puis-je utiliser ce projet pour mon gouvernement ou mon entreprise ?

Oui, il s'agit d'un projet à source ouverte publié sous la licence du MIT et vous pouvez l'utiliser pour vos propres besoins. Voir le lien ci-dessus pour le dépôt du projet.

Veuillez fournir un avis de licence et l'attribution du travail si nécessaire.

Qu'est-ce que l'auto-évaluation DORA ?

C'est un questionnaire conçu pour vous aider à évaluer votre alignement avec les pratiques DevOps selon l'ensemble des mesures de DevOps Research and Assessment (DORA) et à suggérer des moyens possibles d'améliorer votre pratique DevOps.

Comment ça marche ? Les résultats démontreront votre niveau d'alignement et proposeront des moyens d'améliorer certains domaines de votre travail.

Où puis-je trouver mes résultats?

Quand vous aurez rempli le questionnaire, une page de résultats détaillés sera affichée. Vous pouvez l'imprimer ou l'enregistrer au format PDF.

Puis-je enregistrer mes réponses et remplir le questionnaire plus tard ? Lorsque vous souhaitez enregistrer votre progression, cliquez sur le bouton 'Enregistrer' en haut de la fenêtre et sauvegardez le fichier JSON (document texte à structure lisible par machine) dans vos dossiers locaux. Si vous voulez continuer là où vous vous êtes arrêté, cliquez sur le bouton 'Choisir le fichier' et sélectionnez votre fichier JSON sauvegardé.

Mémorisez-vous mes réponses ?

Non. Nous ne mémorisons pas vos réponses et les données restent uniquement dans la mémoire locale de votre navigateur. N'hésitez pas à utiliser cet outil autant de fois que vous le souhaitez.

Toutes les données seront effacées si vous cliquez sur le bouton 'Recommencer'.

pages.description: Please select the sections from which you would like to be evaluated against. By default all of them are enabled.

pages.name: sectionOne

elements.name: section_one_recovery_code_vc
elements.title: We can recover application code from the version control system.

elements.name: section_one_reconfigure_system_vc
elements.title: We can reconfigure systems from files in the version control system.

elements.name: section_one_reconfigure_application_vc
elements.title: It is easy to change code maintained by other teams if we need to.

elements.name: section_one_reprovision_system_scripts_vc
elements.title: It is easy to find examples in our codebase.

elements.name: section_one_change_other_teams_code
elements.title: It is easy to reuse other people’s code.

elements.name: section_one_examples_codebase
elements.title: It is easy to add new dependencies to a project.

elements.name: section_one_easy_migrate_dependency
elements.title: It is easy to migrate to a new version of a dependency.

elements.name: section_one_stable_dependencies
elements.title: Dependencies are stable and rarely break teams’ code.

pages.title: Section One - Version Control and Code Maintainability

pages.name: sectionTwo

elements.name: section_two_commits_trigger_build
elements.title: Code commits result in an automated build of the software.

elements.name: section_two_commits_triggers_tests
elements.title: Code commits result in a series of automated tests being run.

elements.name: section_two_percentage_commits_trigger_automated_tests
elements.title: The % of code commits that result in a suite of automated tests being run without manual intervention.

elements.name: section_two_automated_build_and_tests_executed_successfully
elements.title: Automated builds and tests are executed successfully every day.

elements.name: section_two_percentage_automated_builds_and_tests_successfully
elements.title: The % of automated builds and the percentage of automated tests that are executed successfully every day.

elements.name: question1
elements.title: Current builds are available to testers for exploratory testing.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: Developers get feedback from the acceptance and performance tests every day.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: The % of tests that provide feedback that is available to developers within a day.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: Broken builds are fixed immediately.

elements.name: time
elements.title: How much time between the build breaking and having it fixed, either with a check-in that fixes the problem, or by reverting the breaking change.

elements.name: question5
elements.title: The % of automation in your deployment pipeline.

elements.name: question7
elements.title: How much time spent on delays in the deployment pipeline?

elements.name: question8
elements.title: Adequate test data is available to run full automated test suites.

elements.name: question6
elements.title: Test data for automated test suites can be acquired on demand.

elements.name: question10
elements.title: Test data doesn’t limit or constrain the automated tests that teams can run.

elements.name: question11
elements.title: The % of features that undergo security review early in the design process.

elements.name: question12
elements.title: Security reviews DO NOT slow down the development cycle.

elements.name: question13
elements.title: The % of security requirements that are included in the automated testing process.

elements.name: question14
elements.title: Security supplies teams with an ample number of approved libraries, packages, and toolchains for use.

pages.title: Section Two - Continuous Integration and Deployment

elements.name: question15
elements.title: Developers primarily create and maintain acceptance tests.

elements.name: question16
elements.title: When the automated tests pass, I am confident the software is releasable.

elements.name: question17
elements.title: Test failures are likely to indicate a real defect.

elements.name: question19
elements.title: It is easy for developers to fix acceptance test failures.

elements.name: question18
elements.title: Developers use their own development environment to reproduce acceptance failures.

elements.name: question20
elements.title: Automated tests are seamlessly integrated into our software delivery tech bricks.

elements.name: question21
elements.title: We continuously review and improve our test suite to better find defects and keep complexity and cost under control.

elements.name: question22
elements.title: We have the test data necessary to run our tests easily at every step.

elements.name: question23
elements.title: Testers work alongside developers throughout the software development and delivery process.

elements.name: question24
elements.title: Manual test activities such as exploratory testing, usability testing, and acceptance testing are performed continuously throughout the delivery process.

elements.name: question25
elements.title: Developers practice test-driven development by writing unit tests before writing production code for all changes to the codebase.

elements.name: question26
elements.title: I can get feedback from automated tests in less than ten minutes both on local workstation and from the CI server.

elements.name: question27
elements.title: My team can make large-scale changes to the design of their systems without the permission of somebody outside the team or depending on other teams.

elements.name: question28
elements.title: My team are able to complete work without needing fine-grained communication and coordination with people outside the team.

elements.name: question29
elements.title: My team deploy and release their product or service on demand, independently of the services it depends on or of other services that depend on it.

elements.name: question30
elements.title: My team do most of their testing on demand, without requiring an integrated test environment.

elements.name: question32
elements.title: My team can deploy during normal business hours with negligible downtime.

elements.name: question31
elements.title: My team feels that we’re empowered to choose tools.

elements.name: question33
elements.title: Once I have access, I can independently provision and configure the cloud resources and capabilities required for my product or service on demand without raising tickets or requiring human interaction.

elements.name: question34
elements.title: The service or product that I primarily work on is designed to be accessed from a broad range of devices (e.g. smartphones, tablets, laptops) over the network without the need for proprietary plug-ins or protocols.

elements.name: question35
elements.title: The cloud my product or service runs on serves multiple teams and applications, with compute and infrastructure resources dynamically assigned and re-assigned based on demand.

elements.name: question36
elements.title: I can dynamically increase or decrease the cloud resources available for the service or product that I primarily support based on demand.

elements.name: question37
elements.title: I can monitor or control the quantity and/or cost of cloud resources used by the service or product that I primarily support.

pages.name: sectionSix

elements.name: question38
elements.title: My team is able to work on new ideas and experiment.

elements.name: question39
elements.title: My team is able to do work without having to ask for permission.

elements.name: question40
elements.title: My team is able to make changes to user needs and specifications during a project.

elements.name: question41
elements.title: My team is able to make changes without having to ask for permission.

elements.name: question42
elements.title: Changes can be promoted to production without manual change approvals.

elements.name: question43
elements.title: The % of changes that do (or do not) require a manual change to be promoted to production.

elements.name: question44
elements.title: Production changes don’t need to be approved by an external body before deployment or implementation.

elements.name: question45
elements.title: The amount of time changes spend waiting for approval from external bodies.

elements.name: question46
elements.title: The % of changes that are managed by peer-review.

elements.name: question48
elements.title: My team has a clear understanding of the process to get changes approved for implementation.

elements.name: question47
elements.title: My team is confident they can get changes through the approval process in a timely manner and know the steps it takes to go from “submitted” to “accepted”.

elements.name: question49
elements.title: Tools and platforms are agreed upon by the team and tailored to the needs of the project.

elements.name: question50
elements.title: My team promotes team development and handle cross-functional activities.

elements.name: question51
elements.title: My team executes peer review which includes reviews, comments, and approvals captured as part of the development process.

elements.name: question52
elements.title: How much time do changes spend waiting for approval from external bodies?

elements.name: question53
elements.title: My team considers the development platform as a product by evaluating the changes on multiple axes, including security, performance,and stability, as well as defects.

elements.name: question54
elements.title: My team continuously improve business processes by identifying and eliminating waste.

pages.title: Section 6. Team Experimentation and Streamlining Change Approval

pages.name: sectionSeven

elements.name: question55
elements.title: My team actively collects customer feedback on product and features quality.

elements.name: question56
elements.title: My team establishes key metrics on customer satisfaction before gathering information from the customers.

elements.name: question57
elements.title: After seeking customer feedbacks, the team utilizes the response to understand the pain points and find solutions quickly.

elements.name: question65
elements.title: Current or recent value streams are available in the organizations to help my team fully understand the current situation, from the customer point of view, align on the problem across all roles in the organization

elements.name: question64
elements.title: My team is able to use value streams to gain insight and guide necessary improvements to ensure you have the bandwidth to support functionality and the documentation to put it into place.

elements.name: question63
elements.title: Everyone in the organization have access to a visual display that shows what they’re working on and the status of their work.

elements.name: question62
elements.title: Lead time, process time and %C/A are metrics to analyze the state of work within the value stream and information to determine barriers to flow and each process block.

elements.name: question61
elements.title: My team focuses on building, testing, and releasing code changes to an (production or testing) environment in small batches.

elements.name: question60
elements.title: Following production release, my team is able to amplify feedback from users quickly using techniques (ex: AB testing) and enable short lead times faster.

elements.name: question59
elements.title: Following production release, my team is able to evaluate the results and fix bugs rapidly.

elements.name: question58
elements.title: Feedback received is simple, easy to understand and provides actionable information.

pages.title: Section 7: Customer Feedback and Work Visibility

elements.name: question66
elements.title: In my team data from application performance monitoring tools is used to make business decisions

elements.name: question67
elements.title: In my team data from infrastructure monitoring tools is used to make business decisions

elements.name: question68
elements.title: Monitoring in my team gives rapid feedback which helps quickly find and fix problems early in the project lifecycle?

elements.name: question75
elements.title: In my team the knowledge gained from application monitoring is shared across organization to help people and systems improve.

elements.name: question74
elements.title: In my team collected data is always accessible to different audiences to help them make decisions.

elements.name: question73
elements.title: Our team monitors by taking a thoughtful approach to monitoring which usually draws attention to key areas.

elements.name: question72
elements.title: My team is reporting on the overall health of systems (Are my systems functioning? Do my systems have sufficient resources available?).

elements.name: question71
elements.title: My team is reporting on system state as experienced by customers (Do my customers know if my system is down and how do we know if they have a bad experience?)

elements.name: question70
elements.title: My team has a tooling to help to understand and debug systems in production

elements.name: question69
elements.title: My team has access to tools and data that help trace, understand, and diagnose infrastructure problems in production environment, including interactions between services

pages.name: sectionNine

elements.name: question76
elements.title: People on my team are not often assigned to work on multiple mutually exclusive tasks.

elements.name: question77
elements.title: When faced with too much work and too few people to do it, we prioritize work and focus on completing a small number of high-priority tasks.

elements.name: question78
elements.title: My team often discovers invisible work when it is not expected.

elements.name: question84
elements.title: In my team we do not require people to split their time between multiple tasks.

elements.name: question83
elements.title: Our team work is visible to other teams and stakeholders?

elements.name: question82
elements.title: My team uses visual displays and dashboards to manage the work at various stages of a process.

elements.name: question81
elements.title: How much time does it take to complete a project backlog item?

elements.name: question80
elements.title: In my team visual displays are up to date and the information contributing to measurable improvement is towards a goal that the team cares about.

elements.name: question79
elements.title: When looking at visual management displays I see the key process metrics my team cares about.

pages.title: Section Nine - Work In Process Limits and Visual Management

pages.name: sectionTen

elements.name: question85
elements.title: In my team employees feel supported by each other.

elements.name: question86
elements.title: In my team employees feel their feedback is valued.

elements.name: question87
elements.title: In my team employees are given meaningful work that leverages their expertise.

elements.name: question104
elements.title: My team has support from leaders and managers for the necessary culture shift and transformation.

elements.name: question103
elements.title: My team culture interacts with the broader organizational culture.

elements.name: question102
elements.title: In my team failures are treated as opportunities to improve and learn.

elements.name: question101
elements.title: My team is allowed and encouraged to experiment and try new things.

elements.name: question100
elements.title: On my team, information is actively sought

elements.name: question99
elements.title: Messengers are not punished when they deliver news of failures or other bad news.

elements.name: question98
elements.title: On my team, responsibilities are shared.

elements.name: question97
elements.title: On my team, cross-functional collaboration is encouraged and rewarded.

elements.name: question96
elements.title: On my team, failure causes inquiry.

elements.name: question95
elements.title: On my team, new ideas are welcomed.

elements.name: question94
elements.title: My team views learning as a priority and an investment for growth.

elements.name: question93
elements.title: My team has the resources to engage in informal learning and the space to explore ideas.

elements.name: question92
elements.title: My team has a regular cadence of opportunities for employees to share their knowledge.

elements.name: question91
elements.title: In my team resources are available for continued education.

elements.name: question90
elements.title: When employees in my team attend conferences, we have them share the new experience through presentations or trip reports.

elements.name: question89
elements.title: In my team we encourage people to get certifications or external trainings, and help them by covering costs of external trainings and forming study groups that are a part of normal work activity.

pages.title: Section Ten - Learning and Generative Culture

pages.name: sectionEleven

elements.name: question88
elements.title: My team understands clearly what the current and target conditions are.

elements.name: question105
elements.title: My team is running experiments on a daily basis to try to move toward the target conditions or key results

elements.name: question106
elements.title: The outcomes that my team is working towards match up clearly to the purpose and mission of the organization

elements.name: question119
elements.title: Leaders understand clearly where my team and the organization are going, and where they want the team to be in five years.

elements.name: question118
elements.title: My team understands clearly where they and the organization are going, and where they want the team to be in five years.

elements.name: question117
elements.title: Leaders say positive things about the team.

elements.name: question116
elements.title: Leaders say things that make employees proud to be a part of their organization.

elements.name: question115
elements.title: Leaders encourage people to see changing conditions as situations full of opportunities.

elements.name: question114
elements.title: Leaders challenge team members to think about old problems in new ways and to rethink some of their basic assumptions about their work.

elements.name: question113
elements.title: Leaders have ideas that force team members to rethink some things that they have never questioned before.

elements.name: question112
elements.title: Leaders consider others’ personal feelings before acting.

elements.name: question111
elements.title: Leaders behave in a manner which is thoughtful of others’ personal needs.

elements.name: question110
elements.title: Leaders see that the interests of team members are given due consideration.

elements.name: question109
elements.title: Leaders commend team members when they do a better than average job and acknowledge improvement in quality of team members’ work.

elements.name: question108
elements.title: Leaders personally compliments team members when they do outstanding work.

elements.name: question107
elements.title: My team is able to describe the vision for IITB in a consistent way without having to look it up.

pages.title: Section Eleven - Transformation and Transformational Leadership
